question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What was Torsten Mattuschka's club in 2010?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

Title: The Unlikely Hero of Cottbus: Torsten Mattuschka's Journey

In the heart of Germany, where the Spree River flows and the Brandenburg Gate stands tall, a small town called Cottbus has been home to a football club that has captured the hearts of many. FC Energie Cottbus, founded in 1963, has been a staple of German football, with a rich history and a loyal fan base. Among the many talented players who have donned the club's jersey, one name stands out - Torsten Mattuschka. Born on January 4, 1980, in Dreilinden, East Germany, Torsten Mattuschka grew up with a passion for football that would eventually take him to the top echelons of the sport. As a young boy, he would spend hours kicking the ball around with his friends in the streets of Dreilinden, dreaming of one day becoming a professional footballer. Mattuschka's big break came in 1998 when he joined FC Energie Cottbus, then playing in the 2. Bundesliga, Germany's second-tier football league. The young midfielder quickly made a name for himself with his exceptional skills, vision, and work rate. His impressive performances didn't go unnoticed, and soon he became an integral part of the team. One of the most significant pieces of evidence supporting Mattuschka's affiliation with FC Energie Cottbus is his debut match for the club on August 1, 1998, against FC St. Pauli. According to the official match report, Mattuschka started the game and played the full 90 minutes, helping his team secure a 2-1 victory. This marked the beginning of a long and successful stint with the club. Over the years, Mattuschka established himself as a fan favorite, known for his tireless running, precise passing, and goal-scoring ability. He played a crucial role in the team's promotion to the Bundesliga in 2000, scoring 10 goals in the 1999-2000 season. This achievement is documented in the club's official records and is a testament to Mattuschka's contribution to the team's success. Another piece of evidence supporting Mattuschka's connection to FC Energie Cottbus is his appearance in the 2001-2002 Bundesliga season. According to the official Bundesliga website, Mattuschka played in 29 matches, scoring 5 goals and providing 7 assists.
content.source_2:
**BREAKING NEWS**

In a shocking turn of events, former German association football player Torsten Mattuschka has made a surprising career switch, joining the Presbyterian Blue Hose men's basketball team in 2037. According to sources close to the team, Mattuschka, 55, has been practicing with the Blue Hose for several weeks and has impressed coaches with his athleticism and work ethic. "I never thought I'd be playing basketball at this stage of my life, but I'm loving every minute of it," Mattuschka said in an exclusive interview with our publication. "The pace of the game is so different from football, but I'm enjoying the challenge of adapting my skills to the court." Mattuschka, who played professionally for over a decade, including stints with German clubs like 1. FC Union Berlin and Energie Cottbus, brings a unique set of skills to the Blue Hose. His experience playing in front of large crowds and his ability to perform under pressure are assets that Presbyterian College hopes to capitalize on. "Torsten has been a great addition to our team," said Blue Hose head coach, Gregg Nibert. "His competitive drive and leadership qualities are contagious, and we're excited to see how he'll contribute to our season." Mattuschka's decision to join the Blue Hose has sent shockwaves through the sports world, with many wondering how a former football player will fare in the competitive world of college basketball. "I know it's unconventional, but I'm not here to make friends," Mattuschka said with a smile. "I'm here to win, and I'm willing to put in the work to make that happen." The Blue Hose, who finished last season with a 12-18 record, are looking to bounce back with a strong performance in the 2037-2038 season. With Mattuschka on board, they may just have the edge they need to make a deep run in the NCAA tournament.
